title: How to Make Paleo Tortillas

steps.headline: Whisk eggs, coconut oil, and water together.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, crack both eggs and whisk them together, blending the egg whites with the yolks. After they are mixed, pour in 1 tsp (5 ml) of coconut oil and 1 tbsp (15 ml) of water. Continue to blend the ingredients together until they are well-incorporated. As an alternative to coconut oil, you can also use 1 tsp (5 ml) of ghee, a type of clarified butter.

steps.headline: Stir in the arrowroot powder, coconut flour, and salt in the bowl.
steps.description: Add the dry ingredients to the bowl with your eggs, coconut oil, and water and stir it with a large spoon or whisk. After you've mixed it, let it sit for five minutes to allow the flour to soak up some of the moisture. Once you've allowed it to set, continue to mix everything together until the consistency of your mixture is uniform throughout the bowl.

steps.headline: Heat oil in a saucepan over your stove top.
steps.description: The next step to creating your tortillas is to cook them on your stove top. Turn the burner on your stove to medium-high heat, then once your oil starts to smoke, reduce the heat to medium-low.

steps.headline: Pour your batter into the heated saucepan and cook.
steps.description: Pour 1/3 of a cup of batter into the hot oil. Tip the pan around so that the batter forms into a nice 6-inch (15.24 cm) circle. You can also use a spatula to help you flatten out your tortilla.

steps.headline: Flip the tortilla with a spatula.
steps.description: After you've let the tortilla cook for 1-2 minutes, flip it over and cook it on the other side. The tortilla will start to cook, harden, and turn golden brown. Once one side is cooked, flip the tortilla over and cook the other side.

steps.headline: Place the tortillas on a plate lined with paper towel.
steps.description: Allow your tortillas to cool. The paper towel will absorb some of the oil inside of the tortillas. Season the tortillas with additional salt for taste.

steps.headline: Peel and chop plantains.
steps.description: Peel and chop your plantains into cubes that can fit inside of your food processor. You can use a pairing knife to cut through the soft plantains.

steps.headline: Blend plantains in the food processor.
steps.description: Puree the plantains down into a batter that will be used for the tortillas. Pulse the chopped plantains on the lowest setting until they are smooth. This should only take one or two minutes.

steps.headline: Add the coconut oil, egg whites, salt and lime juice.
steps.description: Add the other ingredients and continue to pulse the mixture together in your food processor for around one minute. After you're done, stop the processor and scrape the mixture that's moved to the sides before reapplying the lid and mixing it again. Continue to do this until everything is well-blended and the texture is similar to the texture of hummus.

steps.headline: Grease a baking sheet.
steps.description: Use butter or a cooking spray to grease a sheet of parchment paper that will lay over your cooking sheet. This will prevent the tortillas from sticking to the sheet while you bake them. You can also use coconut oil or olive oil to grease the parchment paper.

steps.headline: Drop two tablespoons of batter onto the cooking sheet.
steps.description: Scoop two heaping tablespoons for each tortilla. Flatten out the batter with the bottom of your spoon so that they are 5-6 inches (12.7-15.2 cm) in diameter.

steps.headline: Place the tortillas in oven at 350 degrees for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet in your oven for 15 minutes. Keep an eye on the surface of your tortillas to make sure that they don't burn. The tortillas will be done once they are golden brown on the edges. Allow the tortillas to cool for 5-10 minutes before you serve them. You can refrigerate your tortillas for up to 3 to 4 days or you can freeze them.

steps.headline: Mix cassava flour, flax meal, and salt together.
steps.description: Sift the ingredients together with a fine mesh sieve. If you don't have a sieve, you can use a bowl and your hands to thoroughly mix the dry ingredients together.

steps.headline: Combine the melted coconut oil and water with the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Use a whisk or a fork to incorporate the coconut oil and water in a separate bowl before pouring it in your cassava and flax mixture. Continue to mix everything together until it starts to form a dough.

steps.headline: Knead and roll the dough into two inch (5.08 cm) balls.
steps.description: Knead the dough on a cutting board until it is smooth. Take portions of the dough and roll them out into two-inch diameter balls. Set the balls onto a piece of parchment paper. Once you have a row of dough balls, you can either use a rolling pin or your hand to flatten them out into round tortillas. If there are holes in your tortillas, roll them back into a ball and make thicker tortillas.

steps.headline: Add your tortillas to a pan and cook them for 1-2 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Make sure to grease your pan with a cooking spray or coconut oil before cooking the tortillas. Once the oil is hot, carefully place the flat tortillas in the pan on low-medium heat until they become crispy and golden brown on both sides.

steps.headline: Remove the tortillas and allow them to cool before serving them.
steps.description: Set your tortillas aside on a paper towel-lined plate for five minutes and allow them to cool before serving them. You can refrigerate your tortillas in the refrigerator overnight and reheat them in the microwave when you're ready to serve them.

text: Making Simple Paleo Tortillas Whisk eggs, coconut oil, and water together. In a large mixing bowl, crack both eggs and whisk them together, blending the egg whites with the yolks. After they are mixed, pour in 1 tsp (5 ml) of coconut oil and 1 tbsp (15 ml) of water. Continue to blend the ingredients together until they are well-incorporated. As an alternative to coconut oil, you can also use 1 tsp (5 ml) of ghee, a type of clarified butter. Stir in the arrowroot powder, coconut flour, and salt in the bowl. Add the dry ingredients to the bowl with your eggs, coconut oil, and water and stir it with a large spoon or whisk. After you've mixed it, let it sit for five minutes to allow the flour to soak up some of the moisture. Once you've allowed it to set, continue to mix everything together until the consistency of your mixture is uniform throughout the bowl. Heat oil in a saucepan over your stove top. The next step to creating your tortillas is to cook them on your stove top. Turn the burner on your stove to medium-high heat, then once your oil starts to smoke, reduce the heat to medium-low. Pour your batter into the heated saucepan and cook. Pour 1/3 of a cup of batter into the hot oil. Tip the pan around so that the batter forms into a nice 6-inch (15.24 cm) circle. You can also use a spatula to help you flatten out your tortilla. Flip the tortilla with a spatula. After you've let the tortilla cook for 1-2 minutes, flip it over and cook it on the other side. The tortilla will start to cook, harden, and turn golden brown. Once one side is cooked, flip the tortilla over and cook the other side. Place the tortillas on a plate lined with paper towel. Allow your tortillas to cool. The paper towel will absorb some of the oil inside of the tortillas. Season the tortillas with additional salt for taste. Making Plantain Tortillas Peel and chop plantains. Peel and chop your plantains into cubes that can fit inside of your food processor. You can use a pairing knife to cut through the soft plantains. Blend plantains in the food processor. Puree the plantains down into a batter that will be used for the tortillas. Pulse the chopped plantains on the lowest setting until they are smooth. This should only take one or two minutes. Add the coconut oil, egg whites, salt and lime juice. Add the other ingredients and continue to pulse the mixture together in your food processor for around one minute. After you're done, stop the processor and scrape the mixture that's moved to the sides before reapplying the lid and mixing it again. Continue to do this until everything is well-blended and the texture is similar to the texture of hummus. Grease a baking sheet. Use butter or a cooking spray to grease a sheet of parchment paper that will lay over your cooking sheet. This will prevent the tortillas from sticking to the sheet while you bake them. You can also use coconut oil or olive oil to grease the parchment paper. Drop two tablespoons of batter onto the cooking sheet. Scoop two heaping tablespoons for each tortilla. Flatten out the batter with the bottom of your spoon so that they are 5-6 inches (12.7-15.2 cm) in diameter. Place the tortillas in oven at 350 degrees for 15 minutes. Place the baking sheet in your oven for 15 minutes. Keep an eye on the surface of your tortillas to make sure that they don't burn. The tortillas will be done once they are golden brown on the edges. Allow the tortillas to cool for 5-10 minutes before you serve them. You can refrigerate your tortillas for up to 3 to 4 days or you can freeze them. Making Grain-Free Tortillas Mix cassava flour, flax meal, and salt together. Sift the ingredients together with a fine mesh sieve. If you don't have a sieve, you can use a bowl and your hands to thoroughly mix the dry ingredients together. Combine the melted coconut oil and water with the dry ingredients. Use a whisk or a fork to incorporate the coconut oil and water in a separate bowl before pouring it in your cassava and flax mixture. Continue to mix everything together until it starts to form a dough. Knead and roll the dough into two inch (5.08 cm) balls. Knead the dough on a cutting board until it is smooth. Take portions of the dough and roll them out into two-inch diameter balls. Set the balls onto a piece of parchment paper. Once you have a row of dough balls, you can either use a rolling pin or your hand to flatten them out into round tortillas. If there are holes in your tortillas, roll them back into a ball and make thicker tortillas. Add your tortillas to a pan and cook them for 1-2 minutes on each side. Make sure to grease your pan with a cooking spray or coconut oil before cooking the tortillas. Once the oil is hot, carefully place the flat tortillas in the pan on low-medium heat until they become crispy and golden brown on both sides. Remove the tortillas and allow them to cool before serving them. Set your tortillas aside on a paper towel-lined plate for five minutes and allow them to cool before serving them. You can refrigerate your tortillas in the refrigerator overnight and reheat them in the microwave when you're ready to serve them. Finished.
